Unlicensed Medicines Policy/ MSBPO18017 / 1.2

Introduction

In order to ensure that medicines are safe, effective and of appropriate quality, their manufacture and sale or supply is controlled by national and EU legislation. The latter will apply until alternative arrangements, if applicable, are made post- Brexit by the UK government. Accordingly, no medicinal product may be placed on the market unless a marketing authorisation (MA) (formerly product licence) has been granted. However, in order to preserve prescriber clinical freedom, the legislation gives some exemptions from full control. Thus, medicinal products not licensed (i.e. without a MA) may be prescribed in order to fulfil special needs in individual patients. This will be on the direct personal responsibility of the prescribing clinician. Whilst licensed medicinal products are subject to stringent control by the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), neither prescriber nor pharmacist can make the same assumptions of quality, safety and efficacy about unlicensed products.
It is important that the Trust and all of its prescribers and pharmacists should be aware of the medic-legal implications.
The MHRA has set out guidance for the handling of unlicensed medicines in Guidance note  (reference 1):

Pharmacists should have assessed the specific clinical need for the product; ensured that there is no licensed equivalent available, and that the product is of a suitable medicinal quality. This is of particular importance in paediatrics (reference 2)
The prescriber must be aware of the licensed status of a product.
Patients should be informed of the unlicensed status of the medicine.
Details and batch numbers of all unlicensed medicines prescribed, procured, supplied and administered should be recorded.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Purpose 1 - This document describes the Trust policy for the procurement, prescribing and handling of unlicensed medicines to ensure that they are handled safely to minimise risks to patients and that staff are working within legal and regulatory frameworks.

Purpose 2 - The policy applies to all staff that with any role in the procurement, supply, prescribing or administration of unlicensed medicines. Many professions are involved in these activities and must be aware of the relevant sections before undertaking any activities involving unlicensed medicines.

This policy covers the handling of unlicensed medicines. It does not cover the “off licence use” of licensed medicines (including crushing medicines and mixing of medicines in syringe drivers) nor clinical trials. The responsibility for off licence use of medicines remains with the prescriber and any professional administering the medicine. In these situations, the Trust expects best practice to be adhered to including informing patients of the 'unlicensed' use of the medicinal product.
Definitions

table_items.text: A medicinal product, under the terms of the Medicines Act 1968, which has been granted a marketing authorisation for specific indications for human use by the MHRA.

Medicinal products produced in NHS Pharmacy aseptic units and non-sterile manufacturing units where demand does not justify commercial production and licensing. These products do not have a marketing authorisation and therefore no specified indication for use, recommended dose or Summary of Product Characteristics. Examples include using a licensed drug as an ingredient in preparing a medicine e.g. aseptic production of parenteral nutrition or chemotherapy
Marketing Authorisation (formerly known as a product license)
Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency
Where a licensed medicine is used for an unlicensed indication or dosage, as is often the case in paediatric medicine.
Legal document approved as part of the marketing authorisation. It provides information on the use of the medicine e.g. indication, routes of administration, dosing, contra- indications, interactions
A medicinal product that does not hold a current marketing authorisation for any indication in the UK.

Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Duties Are:
Site Clinical Governance Committee (CGC) or equivalent Responsible for:
Ensuring any concerns escalated by MOC (MMC) are appropriately managed corporately.
Medicines Optimisation Committee (MOC) / Medicines Management Committee (MMC) or equivalent
Responsible for:
Agreeing and reviewing this policy.
Ensuring that management, auditing and monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the msb Pharmacy Board.

Appraising unlicensed medicines for use where appropriate; taking into account those requests considered to be appropriate where the benefits to patient care outweigh, on balance, the risks involved to the patient and to the Trust.
Ensuring concerns are escalated to the site clinical governance committee (or equivalent) when unable to resolve.
Pharmacy Board  Responsible for:
Ensuring pharmacy departmental SOPs are maintained and adhered to in accordance with current guidance and legislation.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties Are:
4.5.1 Site Managing Director Responsible for:
Ensuring the Trust site has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
4.5.2 Director of Pharmacy (Group Chief Pharmacist) Responsible for:
Establishing and maintaining a system for the safe handling of unlicensed medicines across the Trust.
4.5.3 Site Director of Nursing Responsible for:
Ensuring that safe systems and practices are followed in clinical areas by nursing and midwifery staff for the use of unlicensed medicines.
4.5.4 Site Medical Director Responsible for:
Ensuring that safe systems and practices involving unlicensed medicines are followed by medical teams.
Ensuring consultants complete declaration forms when required according to this policy.
4.5.4 Site Head of Department, Pharmacy (who may delegate to the Clinical Lead Pharmacist)
Responsible for:
Ensuring all unlicensed medicines use is subject to robust risk assessment, procurement, supply and monitoring.

Ensuring there are systems in place to provide relevant education and training for medical staff, pharmacy staff, nursing staff and allied health professionals in the prescribing, supply and administration of unlicensed medicines.
Ensuring designated pharmacy staff involved in unlicensed medicines management adhere to regulatory guidance, this policy and local procedures.
Ensuring all policies and procedures relating to unlicensed medicines are reviewed in a timely manner and remain up to date in line with current national recommendations.
Ensuring appropriate records are kept relating to prescribing requests, procurement and supply to patients or wards/units for individual patient use.
Reviewing the need for continued use of unlicensed medicines, and providing reports to MOC (MMC) or equivalent.
Ensuring any on site outsourced pharmacies adhere to the Trust policy on unlicensed medicines and provide evidence to assure.
4.5.5 Consultants Responsible for:
Ensuring they complete a declaration form when requested by pharmacy (including any outpatient pharmacies on site).
4.5.6 Prescribers Responsible for:
Ensuring they can justify their clinical actions for prescribing an unlicensed medicine.
Ensuring there is a valid consultant declaration form in place when prescribing an unlicensed medicine.
Informing the patient of the unlicensed nature of the medicine prescribed and explain the rationale for prescribing for them.
4.5.7 Pharmacists Responsible for:
Advising prescribers where appropriate of suitable licensed alternatives to unlicensed medicines.
Ensuring prescribers are aware that they have prescribed an unlicensed medicine.
Supporting consultants in the completion of relevant documentation e.g. declaration forms.

Ensuring that if not professionally satisfied that the choice of medication is justified, they have a professional obligation to refuse to supply it. However, first they must confirm their decision with a directorate/division lead pharmacist (or above) then inform the prescriber of their decision, and document in the patient's healthcare record (including actions and rationale).
4.5.8 Registered healthcare professional that handles, prescribes, dispenses or administers unlicensed medicines
Responsible for:
Complying with Trust policies and procedures in relation to unlicensed medicines.
Ensuring that they have the relevant training and competencies to use unlicensed medicines, where required.
Working within current legislation and within the code of conduct of their professional and regulatory bodies.
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving unlicensed medicines.
Informing the patient of the unlicensed nature of the medicine prescribed and explain the rationale for prescribing for them.
General Principles
The Trust will adopt the following principles for handling of unlicensed medicines:
Pharmacy will source and purchase unlicensed medicines in line with MHRA guidance (see Pharmacy Unlicensed Medicines purchasing procedure).

All unlicensed medicines purchased by Pharmacy are risk assessed using a standard risk assessment tool (see Appendix 1) and assigned a category as detailed below prior to any order being released to obtain a product.

A registered pharmacy professional manufacturing or preparing or dispensing or supplying an unlicensed medicine, or repacking a licensed medicine in response to a prescription or an order, is professionally accountable for any defect which is attributable to his/her own action or omissions, or to those of non-registered pharmacy staff acting under their direction.

A registered pharmacy professional who draws up the specification for, and procures an unlicensed medicine, is professionally accountable for any defect which is attributable to their own actions or omissions.
Unlicensed medicines can only be initiated under the supervision of a consultant. Details of who can prescribe are outlined in section 7 of this policy.
Any new requests for a new unlicensed medicine will be managed through the formulary submission process either as a formulary submission or a one-off request using the approved forms.
There must be a valid ‘declaration of responsibility' form signed by a consultant prior to any purchase and/or supply of unlicensed medicines (see Appendix 2).
To support reminding clinicians of their responsibilities, prescribers will be informed by pharmacy of unlicensed medicines used within their clinical area on a 6 monthly basis.
A list of unlicensed medicines available in the Trust will be available on the Trust site intranet and updated every month by Pharmacy.

Patients are informed of the potential for use of unlicensed medicines whilst being treated as an inpatient via general inpatient literature, and specific information leaflets when an unlicensed medicine is dispensed individually for them (see Appendix 3).
Categorisation of Unlicensed Medicines
Unlicensed medicines will be allocated a risk status following a review using the standard risk assessment tool. They will be assigned one of the following categories:
High Risk

These products are considered to have the highest risk of untoward incidents. Signed consent from the patient is required before treatment may commence. Full compliance with the GN14 guidelines is required. Full recording of batch number and date of issue/administration is required for pharmacy issues and patient administration (via the prescription record or patients notes).

A named consultant will complete a declaration of responsibility form for a named patient and a specific unlicensed medicine. Only the named consultant or their registrar can prescribe the named high risk medicine for the named patient.
Medium Risk

Medium risk unlicensed medicines also require full compliance with the GN14 guidelines. Full recording of batch number and date of issue/administration is required for pharmacy issues and patient administration (via the prescription record or patients notes).

A named consultant will complete a declaration of responsibility form for a named patient or patient group. Only consultants or registrars within the relevant specialty can initiate prescribing of the named medium risk medicines. The physical act of prescribing can be undertaken by junior medical members of the team under the supervision of the relevant consultant / registrar.
Low Risk

Low risk unlicensed medicines represent the lowest risk medicines as identified using a risk assessment tool. These products are typically topical preparations with extensive experience of use obtained from a licensed specials manufacturing unit e.g. Sterile Liquid Paraffin for topical application, or alternative formulations of a licensed preparation e.g. Chloramphenicol preservative free eye drops.

They are treated in the same manner as licensed medicines and will not be subject to special requirements such as recording of batch numbers at patient level. Batch numbers of unlicensed medicines received by Pharmacy are recorded in the same manner as for licensed medicines and recorded on issue.

Manufacturers unlicensed medicines (products prepared by the Trust Pharmacy Technical Services or similar MHRA licensed manufacturing units) will generally be assigned to Low Risk unless there are significant risks associated with the product.
A named consultant will complete a declaration of responsibility form for a named patient or patient group.
The physical act of prescribing can be undertaken by junior medical members of the team under the supervision of the relevant consultant / registrar.

The Site Head of Department, Pharmacy (or delegated to the Site Clinical Lead Pharmacist) will identify any additional actions that need to be taken to manage risk when purchasing an unlicensed medicine. For example, if a routinely used unlicensed injectable (e.g. Adrenaline Injection) needs to be purchased because of a supply shortage, they will ensure all clinical staff who use the product of the change are informed in an appropriate and timely manner.
Unlicensed Products for Non-Pharmaceutical Use
These will not be subject to special requirements such as batch number recording.
Prescribing Unlicensed Medicines
Unlicensed medicines must only be used where their use is clearly justified and their clinical / pharmaceutical benefits are considered to outweigh the risks involved.
Junior medical staff must not initiate prescribing of unlicensed medicines unless under the direction of a consultant or registrar in line with requirements under chapter 6 (categorisation).

When an unlicensed drug is used, medico-legally the responsibility for its use lies with the prescribing doctor. A consultant must ensure there is a completed a declaration of responsibility form that covers the prescribing of a specific unlicensed medicine to a specific patient.
Clinicians must ensure that patients are aware of unlicensed status of a proposed medicine and are given information to support consent.

There must be adequate information in any initial communication to primary care where the intention is for the GP to continue prescribing responsibility for the medicine. This must include the rationale, supporting evidence and why licensed alternatives are inappropriate.
Written consent for high risk unlicensed drugs must be obtained from the patient prior to commencement of treatment using the Trust standard consent form:
For Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust see policy for the consent to examination or treatment.
For Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust see Consent to examination or treatment policy.
For Mid Essex Hospitals Trust see Consent to examination or treatment policy.
Supply of Unlicensed Medicines
High Risk Medicines:
Pharmacy staff will ensure that the prescriber has obtained consent from the patient before supplying any high risk unlicensed medicine.
There must be a valid consultant declaration of responsibility form covering the specific medicine and patient.
High risk unlicensed medicines are only dispensed for individual patients. They will not be supplied as stock to wards and departments.
The batch number of the unlicensed medicine supplied is recorded electronically using the pharmacy stock supply computer system at the time of supply.
The unlicensed Patient Information Leaflet (see Appendix 3) is supplied with the medicine.
Feedback will be collated from patients and clinicians to ensure a positive experience in line with recommendations from the NHS Pharmaceutical QA Committee (see reference 5 to this policy).
Medium Risk medicines:
There must be a valid consultant declaration of responsibility form covering the specific medicine and patient.
Medium risk unlicensed medicines are only dispensed for individual patients. They will not be supplied as stock to wards and departments.
The batch number of the unlicensed medicine supplied is recorded electronically using the pharmacy stock supply computer system at the time of supply.
The unlicensed Patient Information Leaflet (see Appendix 3) will be supplied with the medicine.
Low Risk medicines:
There must be a valid consultant declaration of responsibility form covering the specific medicine and patient.

Low risk unlicensed medicines can be dispensed for individual patients, and as stock for wards and departments. The Site Head of Department, Pharmacy (or delegated to the Site Clinical Lead Pharmacist) is responsible for approving unlicensed medicines on stock lists and provide assurance of a 6- monthly review of unlicensed medicines held as stock at Pharmacy Board. The batch number of the unlicensed medicine supplied is recorded electronically using the pharmacy stock supply computer system at the time of supply.
The unlicensed Patient Information Leaflet (see Appendix 3) will be supplied with the medicine.
Exceptions
Any exceptions from the policy must be agreed by the Site Head of Department, Pharmacy and relevant Clinical Lead(s). These will be reported at MOC (MMC) or equivalent.
Preparation of Unlicensed Medicines
The preparation of unlicensed medicines (e.g. extemporaneous manufacture in the dispensary) must be authorised by the Site Head of Department, Pharmacy (or deputy) before proceeding.
Training Requirements
Pharmacy staff will be trained in accordance with their role-specific induction packs. There are no specific training requirements for other staff.
13 Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Appendix 3: Unlicensed Medicine Patient Information
You have been given a supply of:………………………..

The medicine that the hospital specialist has prescribed for you is classified as an unlicensed medicine. This means that for a variety of reasons it does not have an official U.K. product licence, unlike most medicines prescribed in the UK. This can be for many reasons, for example:
It is awaiting the granting of a UK licence from the Government
No UK manufacturer produces the medicine
It is undergoing a clinical trial
Usage of the medicine is low and therefore it is not economic for the makers to send the product for approval or it would be difficult to get enough patients to do a clinical trial
It has been withdrawn from the UK market
Your specialist at the hospital has prescribed this unlicensed medicine because they feel it is the best treatment for you and there is no suitable UK licensed product available.
Your specialist will have indicated to you whether they or your GP will continue to prescribe this medicine. Your GP should be informed of the reasons why this unlicensed

medicine has been prescribed for you by the specialist including on-going plans for future prescribing and ensuring the treatment remains the best treatment for you. As it is an unlicensed medicine, it will require greater notice to obtain further supplies from the community pharmacist therefore you should liaise with your GP and community pharmacy in advance to ensure you do not run out. We would advise you to approach your practice at least ten days before your medicine runs out. You should also speak to your local pharmacy in advance. If they are going to dispense this medicine, they should contact the following supplier if they need to order the medicine:
Your GP is not obliged to follow the specialist's directions, and may not feel it is in your best interests for this medicine to be prescribed by them. They will explain the reasons to you,

although it will usually be due to concerns regarding adequate monitoring or continuity of supply. In this situation the GP will contact the specialist to ensure appropriate care (including on-going prescriptions and any monitoring) is in place from the hospital.
Please be reassured that your doctor and pharmacist have thought very carefully about what is the best medicine for you. If you have any questions or concerns regarding this medicine,
please talk to your pharmacist, hospital specialist or GP.
To be included in Trust patient literature: Unlicensed medicines:

While you are in Hospital, your Doctor may prescribe an unlicensed medicine for you. This means that for a variety of reasons the medicine does not have an official UK product licence like most medicines in the U.K.
This can be for many reasons, for example:
It is awaiting the granting of a UK licence from the Government
No UK manufacturer produces the medicine
It is undergoing a clinical trial
Usage of the medicine is low and therefore it is not economic for the makers to send the product for approval or it would be difficult to get enough patients to do a clinical trial
It has been withdrawn from the UK market
An unlicensed medicine may be prescribed when your Doctor feels it is the best treatment for you, and there is no suitable UK licensed product available.
If you have any questions or concerns regarding the use of unlicensed medicines during your stay, please talk to your pharmacist or doctor.
